ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Basic lab techniques and lab report writing; paired really nicely with the BIOL 101/102 course, so while we were learning about experimental methods or model organisms in the intro Bio sequence, we were actually working with them in lab, which only added to the learning experience.

This course covers foundational biology concepts, including but not limited to enzyme kinetics, bacteria transformation, developmental genetics, and epidemiology. Students gain experience working with several model organisms, including D. melanogaster (fruit flies), C. elegans (worms), sea urchin, starfish, and zebrafish.

This course provided a broad introduction to foundational biology techniques and model organisms. Examples include PCR, bacterial transformation, ELISA, and organisms like Drosophila and C. Elegans. There were also many opportunities to hone skills such as scientific writing and lab recordkeeping.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The labs themselves are quite enriching, and students have the opportunity to use top-notch equipment while researching with several different model organisms. However, several of the course assignments seemed impractical. Most lab reports were over twenty pages long, and the notebook entries differed greatly from what I am accustomed to writing for my own lab work outside of this course. Given that most scientific journals have a page/word limit and notebook entries should be as concise as possible in real-life lab situations, I wish I would have received more feedback on how to approach these assignments in a more practical manner.

Strengths: opportunity to learn something new each class, very hands-on, highly relevant to conducting research in an actual bio lab, collaborative environment, Professor Moreno prepares detailed lab handouts and guides us through each lab

Weaknesses: the rubrics/scoring guidelines for the lab reports and lab notebook entries were a bit ambiguous

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! I came in with limited experience in labs, and this course was incredibly helpful. Dr. Moreno is incredibly supportive and available if you have any questions, and the labs were engaging and matched incredibly well with the BIOL101/102 sequence. Writing four lab reports and keeping up a lab notebook was also beneficial. It was clear Dr. Moreno was preparing us for working in labs in the future, which was exactly what I needed as someone new to it all. I would definitely recommend this course.

I would recommend this course to students who have little to no prior lab experience, as this course equips students with basic skills for note-taking and grant writing, all while allowing students to gain familiarly with the model organisms they may encounter within an external lab. Professor Moreno even goes above and beyond by listing labs related to each week's experiment that are currently accepting undergraduate researchers. However, I would not recommend this course to students who already have lab experience or upperclassman who need a biology lab solely for the purpose of fulfilling pre-med requirements. In these instances, the extensive work instilled within this course may actually counter some of the more practical writing that students who already have lab experience may be used to.

Yes, if you want hands-on experience with wet lab research and bio techniques. Even as someone who has worked in a molecular bio lab before, I learned a ton of new things. I think it's generally rare to get to work with several model organisms and perform such a range of techniques while working in a single lab, so this course offers a unique opportunity to do just that in a short period. It's also not too strenuous for half a writing credit.
